@sAbakumoff a prior can't just be one guess, it has to be a distribution over guesses. Otherwise wouldn't be able to update
@sAbakumoff a prior can't just be a # like 1/2, it would be a distribution like Beta(1, 1) or Beta(.5, .5). Each has *mean* 1/2 though!

@sAbakumoff "yesterday's posterior is tomorrow's prior" üòâ

But note that your prior/posterior isnt 1/2, it's distribution on (0, 1)

@news3jessica Yes! Great analysis. Though may have been iPhone growing not Android shrinking, as campaign ramped up https://t.co/j8bx8tUV8f
@news3jessica If I saw a good joke or outrageous gaffe in a political speech, I may not send it to all my friends, but I could retweet it
@news3jessica I think that politicians are always under scrutiny (e.g. speeches), but Tweets are easiest to digest/share
@news3jessica I'm not a political blogger or analyst (I work in web company, background in biology), so I could only speculate. But
@news3jessica Look at how 538 has quickly grown to a powerhouse of punditry- science is breaking into politics
@news3jessica I think too little political analysis is data-driven. My analysis was popular for quantifying what had only been gut feeling
@news3jessica So I think separating out the man and the establishment he's joining is interesting for that reason. But as another reason,
@news3jessica If you look at @realrealdonaldt, it's a bot that posts only his Android tweets. Freed of campaign tweets, strangely hypnotic!
@news3jessica Clinton's Twitter is run by her staff, except a few tweets that she signs. Trump's raw appeal comes from "authenticity"
@news3jessica I think unusual part of Trump's twitter is not that the campaign sometimes tweets for him, it's that he tweets so much himself
@news3jessica Generally similar RT/Likes, with exception of photos/links (lower) and manual retweets (much lower) https://t.co/8GfMx8wY9b
@news3jessica Good question! Some people suggested that today, so I've taken a look (to be continued)
@news3jessica And Android never shares pictures/links, iPhone often does (usually campaign business) https://t.co/IH2Pdp5wgK
@news3jessica Time of day differs: Trump tweets from Android early in the morning (starting around 5 ET) https://t.co/9uKCZV6Bb9
@news3jessica Trump uses an Android himself, and all the official campaign tweets come from iPhone. Two ways you can tell difference:
@news3jessica So I downloaded about 1400 tweets (about half/half iPhone and Android) to carry out my analysis comparing source + content
@news3jessica I wanted to quantify this, both to confirm that phones represent different accounts and to see difference in words/emotions
@news3jessica This was inspired by observation that Trump's "Trumpier" tweets are Android, campaign's tweets iPhone: https://t.co/eAWplJ6hXC
@news3jessica I've analyzed the history of @realDonaldTrump's tweets, specifically difference between Android/iPhone https://t.co/HRr4yj30hx

To convert from roman numerals to integer in #rstats:

match(r, as.character(as.roman(1:1000)))

e.g. try r <- c("II", "XIV")
@thelonglab silly me, just realized match() is a much easier way :)

@thelonglab mapvalues or inner_join! e.g.

plyr::mapvalues(x, as.character(as.roman(1:100)), 1:100, warn_missing = FALSE)

@jamesaeddy e.g.

acast() %>% cor() %>% melt

way easier than

spread() %>% select() %>% as.matrix() %>% cor() %>% data.frame() %>% gather()

#rstats tip: If you need to convert to/from roman numerals,

as.character(as.roman(1:100))

will get you

"I" "II" "III" "IV" "V" ...
@jamesaeddy for data frame->data frame, absolutely! I still use melt/acast when input/output needs to be matrix

@jamesaeddy An observation is 1 combination of gene+replicate. Thus 25,000x10 exp becomes 250,000-row tidy dataset, with "expression" col
@jamesaeddy consider case when you have measurement of 25K genes and 20 conditions. one-col-per-gene would put 25,000 observations per row

@jamesaeddy Giving one column per gene (let's say in expression dataset) is giving one row to "all observations in one condition" = untidy
@jamesaeddy gene name is a variable. A gene's expression in cond, or allele in individual, is observation. That's what gets one row
@jamesaeddy @Bioconductor A gene is not a variable
